docs.lead_paragraph: The City Council passed a bill yesterday that would require private companies that have contracts with the city to offer the same benefits to the domestic partners of their employees as they do to spouses. The bill was opposed by some religious groups and by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who plans to veto it. The bill, which was approved by a vote of 43 to 5, with two abstentions, would expand on a 1998 city law that gave domestic partnership benefits to city employees, gay or straight. It is modeled after legislation that has been adopted in recent years in cities around the country, including San Francisco, Los Angeles and Seattle.

headline.main: Council Bill Extends Domestic Partner Rights to Companies Working for the City

docs.abstract: New York City Council passes bill that requires private companies having contracts worth more than $100,000 with city to offer same benefits to domestic partners of their employees as they do to their spouses; would apply to benefits like health insurance, bereavement leave and family medical leave; Mayor Michael R Bloomberg pledges to veto measure; some religious groups oppose bill even after it is amended to allow them to give benefits to either an employee's domestic partner or another household member (M)
docs.snippet: The City Council passed a bill yesterday that would require private companies that have contracts with the city to offer the same benefits to the domestic partners of their employees as they do to spouses. The bill was opposed by some religious...

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Net Inc. said yesterday that its quarterly profit fell by nearly 80 percent and that it would cut 500 jobs as part of a turnaround effort. The company, which is based in Los Angeles and sells health insurance, also forecast that full-year earnings would fall short of Wall Street's and its own estimates because it underestimated the cost of hospital claims. Health Net said it earned $15 million, or 13 cents a share in the quarter in contrast to $72 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.9 billion, from $2.7 billion. Health Net said it would cut 500 jobs and take a $15 million charge in the second quarter for severance as part of its efforts to return to financial health.

headline.main: HEALTH NET SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT FELL ALMOST 80%

docs.abstract: Health Net Inc says quarterly profit fell by nearly 80 percent and it will cut 500 jobs as part of turnaround effort; earned $15 million compared to $72 million year ago; sales rose to $2.9 billion from $2.7 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of private colleges in the state plans group purchases, much like hospitals. The group, the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, announced an agreement with I.B.M. yesterday, the first of what it hopes will be many such bulk-buying agreements, including purchases like health insurance. Under the I.B.M. deal, the 105 colleges in the consortium, their students, faculty members and alumni will be eligible for discounts of $400 to $600 on four to six computer models with list prices ranging between $1,200 and $2,100. Eligible machines will change and equipment besides computers will also be available. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Colleges Announce Bulk-Buying Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Texas leads the nation in the percentage of working people who have no health insurance, but the lack of coverage is a pervasive problem for workers in nearly every state, according to a new study for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The study also found that being uninsured has clear health consequences. People without coverage were less likely to get basic preventive care, like mammograms; less likely to have a personal physician; and more likely to rate their own health as only poor or fair.

headline.main: Texas Leads Nation in Percentage of Uninsured Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: Homer Avila, a dancer and choreographer who went on to a new career in dance after the amputation of his cancerous right leg and hip, died on April 27 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 48. The cause was the spread of cancer to his lungs, said Ivan Sygoda, a colleague and friend.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Schering-Plough Corporation agreed to pay $27 million to settle allegations that it defrauded the Medicaid program in Texas, the Justice Department and the Texas attorney general said yesterday. The government accused the company's Warrick Pharmaceuticals unit of submitting false price information that led providers to submit inflated reimbursement claims for drugs used to treat asthma and other respiratory conditions. Schering-Plough said the settlement payment would come from litigation reserves already set aside. The Justice Department said an investigation into Warrick's actions in other states was continuing.

headline.main: SCHERING TO PAY $27 MILLION IN MEDICAID SETTLEMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The article ''Time Heals'' describes a man with untreatable liver disease -- ''sent home to die'' -- who did not need more time in a hospital. The difficult symptoms of his advanced disease could have been better managed at home. Hospice patients are regularly visited by nurses who teach family members how to care for their loved ones. The nurses act as case managers, calling in other hospice team members as needed.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Time Heals, but It's a Luxury Physicians and Patients Rarely Get'' (April 27): When I had an appendectomy, I was discharged by my surgeon within a day, despite my drugged pleas. Later, when I told my doctor that I was forced out of the hospital before I could recover, he exploded. He said medicine was a business now, and if I wanted another day of rest I should have spent a night at the Waldorf Astoria. It would have cost as much as a night in the hospital, he said.
docs.abstract: Pamela W McFeely letter on April 27 article about lack of hospitalization time given to patients agrees that ill people are rushed out of hospitals (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Research Service says the Bush administration apparently violated federal law by ordering the chief Medicare actuary to withhold information from Congress indicating that the new Medicare law could cost far more than White House officials had said. In a report on Monday, the research service said that Congress's ''right to receive truthful information from federal agencies to assist in its legislative functions is clear and unassailable.'' Since 1912, it said, federal laws have protected the rights of federal employees to communicate with Congress, and recent laws have ''reaffirmed and strengthened'' those protections.

headline.main: Agency Sees Withholding of Medicare Data From Congress as Illegal

docs.abstract: Congressional Research Service says Bush administration apparently violated federal law by ordering Richard S Foster, chief Medicare actuary, to withhold information from Congress indicating that new law could cost far more than White House officials had said; Foster has testified that he was ordered by Medicare administrator Thomas Scully to withhold cost estimates; administration begins campaign to persuade millions of older Americans to enroll for prescription drug discount cards, interim measure until January 2006 when Medicare's drug benefit begins (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Manhattan said yesterday that the single largest insurer at the World Trade Center was limited to a single payout of $877 million, not the double payment sought by the developer Larry A. Silverstein in his long-running legal battle over the downtown complex. It was another blow to Mr. Silverstein's 29-month campaign to collect $7.1 billion for rebuilding the trade center site and one that could ultimately force him to settle with 10 remaining insurance companies. Last week, the jury ruled that eight of the two dozen insurers at the trade center were not liable for double payments.

headline.main: U.S. Jury Limits Payout of Trade Center's Biggest Insurer

docs.abstract: Federal jury rules that eight of 24 insurers of World Trade Center are not liable for double payments and that largest insurer Swiss Re is limited to single payout of $877 million; developer Larry A Silverstein was seeking double payments from insurers, contending that two planes hitting two towers should be seen as two separate acts; can now get maximum payout of $4.5 billion if he wins every other legal case; photo (M)
